samples.question: What kinds of television programs do you like watching?
samples.transcript: Did you like the same kinds of TV programs when you were Funk.
samples.transcript_original: Did you like the same kinds of TV programs when you were Funk.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Did you like the same kinds of TV programs when you were Funk.

samples.question: First question, what kinds of television programs do you like watching?
samples.transcript: I am really into documentaries, especially ones about history or true crime. I love getting drawn into real life stories, and I suppose they are a great way to learn something without feeling like you are studying. That said, sometimes I just want to switch off, so I will watch a good comedy or a light-hearted series. Second question.
samples.transcript_original: I'm really into documentaries, especially ones about history or true crime. I love getting drawn into real life stories, and I suppose they're a great way to learn something without feeling like you're studying. That said, sometimes I just want to switch off, so I'll watch a good comedy or a light-hearted series. Second question.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I am really into documentaries, especially ones about history or true crime. I love getting drawn into real life stories, and I suppose they are a great way to learn something without feeling like you are studying. That said, sometimes I just want to switch off, so I will watch a good comedy or a light-hearted series. Second question.

samples.question: Did you like the same kinds of TV programs when you were young?
samples.transcript: Not really. As a kid, I was all about cartoons and adventure shows, programs that were fun and fast-paced. I was not into anything too serious, but as I got older, my tastes changed. I started enjoying more thoughtprovoking stuff like dramas and documentaries. I guess it just comes with growing up.
samples.transcript_original: Um, not really. As a kid, I was all about cartoons and adventure shows, programs that were fun and fast-paced. I wasn't into anything too serious, but as I got older, my tastes changed. I started enjoying more thoughtprovoking stuff like dramas and documentaries. I guess it just comes with growing up.

I was not into anything too serious, but as I got older, my tastes changed. I started enjoying more thoughtprovoking stuff like dramas and documentaries. I guess it just comes with growing up.

samples.question: Third question, what types of television programs are most popular in your country?
samples.transcript: Well, reality TV shows seem to be extremely popular. People love those based on competitions, things like cooking contests or talent shows. And of course, dramas are huge, especially ones with gripping storylines. But I would also have to say that streaming services have changed things a lot. So now people want a mix of both international and local productions. Fourth question.

And of course, dramas are huge, especially ones with gripping storylines. But I'd also have to say that streaming services have changed things a lot. So now people want a mix of both international and local productions. Fourth question.

And of course, dramas are huge, especially ones with gripping storylines. But I would also have to say that streaming services have changed things a lot. So now people want a mix of both international and local productions. Fourth question.

samples.question: Is there anything you do not like about watching TV?
samples.transcript: Yeah, definitely. I think the biggest downside is how addictive it can be. it is so easy to say just one more episode and suddenly you have wasted hours. Also, some shows feel a bit repetitive, like they have the same plot lines just recycled. And of course, the ads can be really interruptive and annoying. Please let me know in the comments what you thought of these part one questions. Now.

samples.question: How did you go with these questions?
samples.transcript: To help you evaluate, you can compare your responses to how I respond. Listen for whether I answer the questions in a general way and whether I develop my answers.

samples.question: First question, how have eating habits changed over the past few decades?
samples.transcript: Well, eating habits have changed dramatically over the last few decades. People used to cook at home more often, but now with busy lifestyles, there is a shift towards convenience, which means people are eating more ready meals, takeaways, and eating out more. there is also been a big rise in healthconscious eating. You see more organic food, plant-based diets, and people cutting down on sugar. In saying that, ultrarocessed foods are also more common than ever. For example, in many cities, you will find fast food joints on every street corner, which was not really the case 30 years ago. If this trend continues, we might see even more health related problems in the future.
samples.transcript_original: Well, eating habits have changed dramatically over the last few decades. People used to cook at home more often, but now with busy lifestyles, there's a shift towards convenience, which means people are eating more ready meals, takeaways, and eating out more. There's also been a big rise in healthconscious eating. You see more organic food, plant-based diets, and people cutting down on sugar. In saying that, ultrarocessed foods are also more common than ever. For example, in many cities, you'll find fast food joints on every street corner, which wasn't really the case 30 years ago. If this trend continues, we might see even more health related problems in the future.

People used to cook at home more often, but now with busy lifestyles, there is a shift towards convenience, which means people are eating more ready meals, takeaways, and eating out more. there is also been a big rise in healthconscious eating. You see more organic food, plant-based diets, and people cutting down on sugar. In saying that, ultrarocessed foods are also more common than ever. For example, in many cities, you will find fast food joints on every street corner, which was not really the case 30 years ago. If this trend continues, we might see even more health related problems in the future.

samples.question: Second question, do you think fast food culture has affected the tradition of sharing meals?
samples.transcript: Yeah, I think so. Fast food has made eating more individualistic. People often grab a burger on the go instead of sitting down for a proper meal. Traditionally, meals were a social event, especially in cultures where family dinners were important. But now with things like food delivery apps, people eat at different times in front of screens or even alone, even when they are in the same home. This kind of change is a bit of a shame and could have quite negative consequences on family dynamics, especially.
samples.transcript_original: Yeah, I think so. Fast food has made eating more individualistic. People often grab a burger on the go instead of sitting down for a proper meal. Traditionally, meals were a social event, especially in cultures where family dinners were important. But now with things like food delivery apps, people eat at different times in front of screens or even alone, even when they're in the same home. This kind of change is a bit of a shame and could have quite negative consequences on family dynamics, especially.

This kind of change is a bit of a shame and could have quite negative consequences on family dynamics, especially.

samples.question: Third question, in what ways do people's eating habits differ between younger and older generations?
samples.transcript: There is definitely a contrast. Older generations tend to prefer home-cooked meals and traditional recipes, while younger people experiment more with different cuisines like Persian and Sri Lankan food or fusion food. Plus, young people often eat on the move, relying on fast food or a meal prep services, whereas older people usually sit down for meals. Another big difference is social media. Young people are influenced by food trends online like superfoods or veganism. But one thing's for sure, both groups seem to be becoming more aware of the importance of nutrition for general health, which is a good thing for society overall.

samples.question: What kind of place is it?
samples.transcript: I was born in Ho Chi Min City, which is the second largest city in Vietnam. it is located in the south of Vietnam.

samples.question: What is the most interesting part of the city?
samples.transcript: The most interesting place about this place, you can pretty much find everything in the city from cultural events to food scenes. they are all at your fun store. it is not far from Australia about 8 hours by plan. So this is attract a lot of tourists coming to visit every year. The most important thing is that the people are super friendly even though they do not speak a lot of English, but they will try to go beyond their way to help you to navigate the city.

samples.question: What kind of jobs do people do in your city?

samples.question: Would you say it is a good place to live?
samples.transcript: To me is a wonderful place to live because there is always something going on in there such as international concert, cultural event and food festival. It is easy to get around now with motorcycle and Ho Chi Min City is now recently built a new train system which is so easy for the local and tourists to get around and from too. More importantly, the cost of living is quite affordable so you can live comfortably there when you have a stable job. I would like to move on to talk about food and cooking.

samples.question: Now, what kind of new food would you like to try?

So during that time they be able to share the story of what the day happening what what what are they exciting for about in the future.
